item.title: Harris unscathed after walking careful line in first interview
item.description: There was no new ammunition for Republicans, but it highlighted the challenge she faces in pitching herself as a change candidate.

item.title: Maduro Appears to Send Two Foreign Members of Ukraine’s Military to Face Trial in Russia
item.description: Two Colombian soldiers who had fought for Ukraine are now under arrest in Moscow. They wound up there after stopping over in Venezuela, which apparently extradited them.

item.title: A Hong Kong court convicts 2 journalists in a landmark sedition case - NPR
item.description:
1. A Hong Kong court convicts 2 journalists in a landmark sedition case  NPR
  2. Two Stand News journalists in Hong Kong found guilty of sedition  The Guardian
  3. Hong Kong prepares for Stand News verdict in latest media freedom test  Al Jazeera English
  4. "A point of no return": the fall of Stand News, Hong Kong's once leading online media outlet  Reuters
  5. Hong Kong Editors Convicted of Sedition in Blow to Press Freedom  The New York Times

item.title: Did Barron Trump say he earned respect of those willing to sacrifice for the country?
item.description: A screenshot claiming to show a message from Barron Trump, asserting he has earned the respect of those willing to sacrifice for the country, is not from an official account. Trump spokesperson and Melania Trump's office confirmed that Barron has no active social media presence and did not make such a statement. The post appears on an account named “Barron Trump New,” which is not affiliated with the Trump campaign.

item.title: Labour MP accused of renting out ant-infested flats with black mould
item.description:
Jas Athwal, the Ilford South MP, denies allegation from tenants that ‘ants are everywhere’ in his properties

A newly elected Labour MP has been accused of renting out flats with black mould and ant infestations.

Jas Athwal, the member for Ilford South and leader, owns 15 rental flats, according to a report by the BBC.

Continue reading...

item.title: Will Labour resist the ‘killer tactics’ of industry’s enemies of public health?
item.description:
Vested interests in food, drink and tobacco companies impede health measures – the wooing of MPs is an insidious practice that provides a test of the new government

  • MPs urged to give up freebies from tobacco, alcohol and junk food firms

Illness, disease and death can be the result of bad luck, genetic factors or people’s lifestyles – whether someone smokes, drinks a lot or consumes a lot of junk food, for example.

The role of lifestyle in explaining why the UK is an increasingly sick country, and the growing pressures on the NHS, is often under-appreciated. Experts tend to cite the growing and, especially, ageing population, which are both key factors.

Continue reading...

item.title: UK MPs urged to give up freebies from tobacco, alcohol and junk food firms
item.description:
Health groups challenge Starmer to ban ‘unhealthy products’ firms from lobbying MPs by giving them gifts

MPs are being urged to stop accepting freebies to sports and cultural events from tobacco, alcohol and junk food firms because their products cause so much illness and death.

More than 100 health groups are urging Britain’s lawmakers to reject offers of gifts and hospitality from “unhealthy products industries” because they use an array of underhand tactics to disguise the harm they create in order to protect their sales.

Continue reading...

item.title: Ex-TV news presenter Mike Nesbitt set to return as Ulster Unionists’ leader
item.description:
Health minister at Stormont was the sole candidate to replace Doug Beattie when nominations shut

The former television news presenter Mike Nesbitt is to become the leader of the Ulster Unionist party for the second time, succeeding Doug Beattie who quit last week.

Nesbitt, 67, who led the UUP between 2012 and 2017, was the only declared candidate when nominations closed on Friday evening. He is expected to be formally ratified as leader at an extraordinary general meeting of the party on 14 September.

Continue reading...

item.title: Anti-abortion groups warn Trump’s row back on position risks losing votes
item.description:
Republican candidate’s comments seen by Democrats as hypocritical and ‘sadden’ anti-abortion activists

Over the last two weeks, Donald Trump has publicly backed away from multiple anti-abortion positions – a move that Democrats see as hypocritical and that, anti-abortion activists warn, risks alienating voters who have long stood by him.

On Thursday, Trump said that, if elected, he would make the government or insurance companies cover in vitro fertilization – a type of fertility assistancethat some in the anti-abortion movement want to see curtailed. Trump also seemed to indicate that he planned to vote in favor of a ballot measure to restore abortion access in Florida, which currently bans abortion past six weeks of pregnancy. “I am going to be voting that we need more than six weeks,” Trump told NBC News in an interview.

Continue reading...

item.title: Major publishers sue Florida over ‘unconstitutional’ school book ban
item.description:
Hundreds of titles from Judy Blume to Mark Twain purged from school libraries following rightwing challenges

Six major book publishers have teamed up to sue the US state of Florida over an “unconstitutional” law that has seen hundreds of titles purged from school libraries following rightwing challenges.

The landmark action targets the “sweeping book removal provisions” of House Bill 1069, which required school districts to set up a mechanism for parents to object to anything they considered pornographic or inappropriate.

Continue reading...
